Portal 2 takes the first game and improves on it in almost every way. Atmospherically, the game is borderline flawless. The developers do a fantastic job of giving the player a sense of time and place, showing the once spotless testing facility in a state of disrepair and decay. Plants grow through crumbling walls, rubble is strewn over cracked floors, the lights flicker and go out. The details are all there and all important in building that sense of decrepitude that haunts the game. And of course, the writing remains fucking incredible. Wheatley is brought to life by Stephen Merchant's incredible performance, which captures all the tics and imperfections of natural speech with incredible fidelity. The story is once again exceptional stuff, having the same sardonic humour, clever twists, and delightful feeling of suspense as the first, except with a much larger scope, better presentation, and that overall polish that I felt was lacking in the first.

The only fumble I'd say is pacing, and I only say this because I think there were things that could have improved it. My primary complaint resides with the fact that the old testing chambers explored in the second half of the game are voiced by Cave Johnson, who is very similar to GLaDOS. This makes sense for the narrative, as it provides the basis of an explanation for GLaDOS's personality, but if I'm being honest with you, that explanation wasn't exactly necessary. Caroline was, as her inclusion lends itself to Portal 2's incredible conclusion, but Cave Johnson is too similar to GLaDOS to even register. Given how different and well realised GLaDOS and Wheatley are, I expected any further addition to the roster to be as original and compelling as its peers. But something about Johnson falls a bit short. I ended up experiencing a bit of burnout on the segment, especially seeing as the goo puzzles weren't as fun to solve as the others.
